{
  "article_text": [
    "one of the main astrophysical targets of lisa @xcite , a space - based interferometric gravitational wave detector , is the gravitational waves generated by the inspiral of compact objects into massive black holes . to extract physical information of such extreme mass ratio inspirals ( emri ) , it is important to know the theoretical gravitational waveforms with sufficient accuracy . for the emri scenario ,",
    "we use the black hole perturbation approach to compute waveforms . here",
    "the compact object is approximated by a point particle orbiting a massive kerr black hole . in order to obtain the precise theoretical gravitational waveforms we need to solve the self - force problem @xcite and then for second order perturbations @xcite .",
    "it has already been over two years that numerical relativity produced one of the most spectacular breakthroughs in science @xcite , succeeding in solving the two body problem in general relativity after decades of effort . among the notable set of results , the discovery @xcite of large recoil velocities ( up to @xmath1 ) @xcite stands out .",
    "notably in ref .",
    "@xcite a generic binary black hole case was treated , with unequal spins and unequal masses ( mass ratio 1/2 ) .",
    "it has been hard to deal with extreme mass ratios and recent computations limit to @xmath2 @xcite for spinning holes and up to nearly 1/4 for nonspinning holes @xcite .",
    "it is foreseeable that soon mass ratios of nearly 1/10 can be achieved in this full numerical simulations making possible a comparison with the semi - analytic approach of the self - force .",
    "the self force problem was formally resolved over ten years ago @xcite , but its implementation in explicit computations proved lengthy and difficult .",
    "this have been reformulated in a more elaborated way by detweiler and whiting @xcite .",
    "the first corrections to the trajectory of an emri was computed in @xcite for a headon collision using the regge - wheeler gauge and the @xmath3-function regularization .",
    "those results were later confirmed using the standard formalism @xcite in the lorenz gauge @xcite . in order to compute the generic orbit corrections around a schwarzschild black hole ,",
    "barack and lousto @xcite have approached the problem of directly solving the linearized einstein equations in the lorenz gauge instead of the regge - wheeler and zerilli wave equations @xcite . to do that , one needs to be able to develop an accurate algorithm to integrate ten coupled wave - like equations with sources proportional to a dirac s delta .",
    "this algorithm has been developed @xcite for the ( 1 + 1)-wave equation resulting from the tensor harmonic decomposition of perturbations in the schwarzschild background , but not for the ( 2 + 1)-equation resulting from perturbations of a kerr ( spinning ) black hole .",
    "this is the subject of the current work .    in this paper",
    ", we focus on one aspect of the self - force problem , specifically to derive the full , bare or retarded field of a point source .",
    "therefore , we do not treat the local analysis of the field around the particle s location because the retarded field is global . here ,",
    "instead of studying the teukolsky equation for the curvature perturbations @xmath4 , as a first step , we consider the klein - gordon equation in the schwarzschild spacetime , but do not decompose it into spherical harmonics , in order to model perturbations like in the more generic kerr background .",
    "recently , introducing a thin worldtube surrounding the worldline of a point particle , barack and golbourn @xcite have discussed this equation in ( 2 + 1)-dimensions as derived by the mode decomposition in the azimuthal direction .",
    "a different treatment is proposed here to deal with this problem globally .",
    "there is also a method to approximate a dirac s @xmath0-function by narrow gaussian @xcite .",
    "it is , however , difficult to ascertain the error introduced by smearing the particle and if this is accurate enough for self force computations .",
    "once we obtain the retarded field , each azimuthal mode of the self - force on the particle can be calculated and is finite at the particle location .",
    "but the summation over all azimuthal modes diverges .",
    "therefore , we need some regularization to derive the regularized self - force . at this stage , it is necessary to discuss the local analysis of the field or self - force in the derivation of the singular part .",
    "the regularized self - force includes two parts , i.e. , the conservative part and the dissipative part @xcite . to obtain the conservative part of the self - force",
    ", we need the regularization , while it is not necessary for the dissipative part which is derived by using a radiative green s function @xcite .",
    "recently , barack , golbourn and sago formulated a new scheme to construct the regularized self force directly from the azimuthal modes of the field in @xcite .",
    "the paper is organized as follows . in",
    ", we discuss the ( 2 + 1)-dimensional klein - gordon differential equation with a 2-dimensional @xmath0-function as a source . to remove the @xmath0-function",
    ", we introduce a new wave - function .",
    "this formulation is done in the case of general orbits in the schwarzschild background . in ,",
    "we apply the formulation given in to the case of circular orbits . here , we obtain a global effective source which is well behaved everywhere .",
    "to do so , we also treat boundary behaviors both near the black hole horizon and at spatial infinity . in",
    ", we summarize the results of this paper and discuss its applications .",
    "some details of the calculations are given in the appendices . throughout this paper",
    ", we use units in which @xmath5 .",
    "when we calculate the ( 2 + 1)-dimensional equation derived from the 4-dimensional klein - gordon equation by the azimuthal mode decomposition , the resulting equation is not exactly same as the ( 2 + 1)-dimensional wave equation . in our formulation , it is important to derive a differential operator which is the ( 2 + 1)-dimensional dalambertian of the flat spacetime . by transforming the scalar field",
    ", we can obtain an equation which includes the flat ( 2 + 1)-dimensional dalambertian and a remainder as in below .",
    "then , we remove the 2-dimensional @xmath0-function in the source term by using the green s function method .    in order to obtain the flat dalambertian",
    ", we consider the schwarzschild metric in the isotropic coordinates , @xmath6 \\ , .",
    "\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] this radial coordinate is related to that of the schwarzschild , r , @xmath7 in the above coordinates , the klein - gordon equation with a point source reads @xmath8   \\times \\psi(t,\\rho,\\theta,\\phi )   \\nonumber \\\\",
    "\\hspace{-10 mm } = - q \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty } d\\tau   \\frac{64\\rho^4\\delta(t - t_z(\\tau))\\delta(\\rho-\\rho_z(\\tau))\\delta(\\theta-\\theta_z(\\tau ) ) \\delta(\\phi-\\phi_z(\\tau ) ) } { ( 2\\rho - m)(2\\rho+m)^5 \\sin\\theta }    \\ , , \\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where @xmath9 and @xmath10 denote a scalar field and a scalar charge , respectively .",
    "@xmath11 is the particle s trajectory with a proper time @xmath12 . here",
    ", we use the azimuthal mode decomposition , @xmath13 and then obtain the wave equation for each @xmath14 mode as @xmath15 \\psi_m(t,\\rho,\\theta )   \\nonumber \\\\",
    "\\hspace{-10 mm } = - q \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty } d\\tau   \\frac{64\\rho^4\\delta(t - t_z(\\tau))\\delta(\\rho-\\rho_z(\\tau))\\delta(\\theta-\\theta_z(\\tau ) ) } { ( 2\\rho - m)(2\\rho+m)^5 \\sin\\theta } \\exp[-i m \\phi_z(\\tau ) ] \\ , .",
    "\\label{eq : psimeq}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] for the above equation , we transform the field @xmath16 as @xmath17^{1/2 } \\ , \\chi_m(t,\\rho,\\theta ) \\ , .",
    "\\label{eq : scalartrans}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] above , we have set the radial and angular factors to obtain the spatial part of the flat ( 2 + 1)-dimensional dalambertian . then , @xmath18 satisfies the following equation @xmath19 \\biggr\\ } \\chi_m(t,\\rho,\\theta )   \\nonumber \\\\ \\hspace{-10 mm } = - q \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty } d\\tau   \\frac{2\\,\\delta(t - t_z(\\tau))\\delta(\\rho-\\rho_z(\\tau))\\delta(\\theta-\\theta_z(\\tau ) ) } { \\left[{(2\\rho - m)(2\\rho+m)\\rho \\sin\\theta}\\right]^{1/2 } }   \\exp[-im \\phi_z(\\tau ) ] \\ , .",
    "\\label{eq : medwe}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] note that from the relation @xmath20 , the source term for @xmath18 becomes @xmath21 times that for @xmath16 .",
    "this fact will be used in .",
    "next , we define a new time coordinate @xmath22 where @xmath23 is obtained by solving the geodesic equation and we use the fact that the proper time @xmath12 and the argument @xmath24 in @xmath23 are also related by the geodesic equation . from this , we derive an equation which can be divided into the ( 2 + 1)-dimensional dalambertian of the flat case @xmath25 and a remainder . @xmath26 where the differential operators are given by @xmath27\\partial_t^2 \\nonumber \\\\",
    "\\hspace{-10 mm } - \\frac{2 ( 4\\rho_z(t)-m ) ( 2\\rho_z(t)-m)(2\\rho+m)^6 \\rho_z(t)^3 m } { ( 2\\rho_z(t)+m)^7(2\\rho - m)^2\\rho^4 } \\left(\\frac{d\\rho_z(t)}{dt}\\right ) \\partial_t \\nonumber \\\\ \\hspace{-10 mm } -\\frac{1}{\\rho^2 \\sin^2 \\theta } \\left[m^2 - \\frac{1}{4}\\frac{(4\\rho^2+m^2)^2 - 16\\rho m \\cos^2 \\theta } { ( 2\\rho+m)^2(2\\rho - m)^2 } \\right ]   \\ , ,   \\label{eq : dfdecomp}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] and the source term is shown to be @xmath28^{1/2 } }   \\exp[-im \\phi_z(\\tau ) ] \\ , .",
    "\\label{eq : formalsource}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] here , it is noted that there is no @xmath29 and @xmath30 derivatives in @xmath31 of because all @xmath29 and @xmath30 derivatives are included in @xmath25 .    to remove the @xmath0-function in the source term ,",
    "we set @xmath32 where we define the new functions , @xmath33 and @xmath34 as calculated from @xmath35 the effective source @xmath36 contains no @xmath0-function",
    ". does not have any physical - meaning , i.e. , @xmath33 is not identified as the singular part to be removed in the self - force calculation .",
    "the physically and mathematically - meaningful singular part of the field which is called as the @xmath37-part , have been discussed in @xcite .",
    "recently , vega and detweiler @xcite have discussed a new method to derive the retarded field by using a specific approximation to the @xmath37-part . ]",
    "note that @xmath31 includes a second - order derivative .",
    "but , since the factor of @xmath38 is zero at the particle location , the singular behavior of the effective source @xmath36 weakens .",
    "the derivation of the singular field @xmath33 can be performed through the green s function of the ( 2 + 1)-dimensional flat case , @xmath39^{1/2 } } \\theta((t - t')-|{\\bf x } - { \\bf x'}| )   \\ , , \\label{eq : green}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where @xmath30 denotes the heaviside step function , @xmath40 is a 2-dimensional spatial vector and the spatial distance is defined by @xmath41^{1/2 } \\,.\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] some detail on the above green s function is discussion in .",
    "next , @xmath33 is calculated by the following integral @xmath42 here , it should be noted that the green s function in the above multiple integration is given by analytically .",
    "therefore , it is easy to perform the integration in even for general orbits .    as for the remaining field @xmath34",
    ", we use numerical integrations .",
    "however , the effective source @xmath36 is not amenable for direct numerical integrations due to its non - continuous behavior at the particle location . to explicitly obtain a source term well behaved everywhere",
    ", we will apply the formulation discussed above to the case of a particle on a circular orbit .",
    "we consider a particle in a circular orbit given by @xmath43 where @xmath44 denotes the orbital radius in schwarzschild coordinates .",
    "the four velocity @xmath45 is written by @xmath46^{1/2}\\ , . \\ ] ]    the relationship between the new time coordinate @xmath47 and the schwarzschild time @xmath24 can be obtained analytically @xmath48 where @xmath49 note that in general , for non circular orbits , we need a numerical integration to derive this relationship .    in order to calculate the singular field , the green s function in is rewritten in terms of @xmath24 as @xmath50^{1/2 } } \\nonumber \\\\ & \\quad \\times   \\theta \\left(\\frac{4\\,(2\\rho_0-m)\\rho_0 ^ 2}{(2\\rho_0+m)^3}(t - t')-|{\\bf x } - { \\bf x'}| \\right ) \\,.\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] in the following , we will discuss the @xmath51 and @xmath52 modes separately .",
    "the effective source for a final regularized function @xmath53 must go like @xmath54 for @xmath55 in the case of the @xmath51 mode and @xmath56 for the @xmath52 mode .",
    "the reason is the following .",

    ", in practice , we will calculate the regularized function of the original field @xmath16 numerically .",
    "this means that the source term which we will use in the numerical calculation , becomes the factor @xmath60 times the source for @xmath53 .",
    "thus , since we integrate the second order differential equation of , we need the above integrability conditions . in a similar manner , at the black hole horizon ,",
    "i.e. , @xmath61 , the source for @xmath62 should vanish , i.e. , the behavior of the source for @xmath53 should be a power of @xmath63 greater than @xmath64 because the source for @xmath16 is the factor @xmath65 times the source for @xmath53 .        in the schwarzschild background ,",

    "mode , we also set @xmath80 and use the real part of sources . ]",
    "there is a singular behavior at the particle location . in order to perform the numerical integration with higher accuracy ,",
    "it is convenient to regularize the source term to be at least @xmath81 at the particle location .    in order to obtain the source @xmath82 which is regular at the particle location ,",
    "we choose the regularization function @xmath83 as @xmath84 this regularization function is chosen such that the additional source which arises from this function behaves well both for large @xmath29 and at the horizon . here",
    ", the factors of the power of @xmath85 and @xmath86 in the above equation give this good behavior .",
    "( we will discuss the @xmath52 case by using the same treatment for the regularization function . )",
    "although this regularization function ( and the other regularization functions discussed later ) is clearly not unique , the sum of the regularization functions and the regularized function , i.e. , the ( original ) retarded function has the physical - meaning and is unique .",
    "this is because the source for the regularized function changes by differences of the regularization functions .",
    "therefore , one may construct any appropriate source by which we can derive a regularized function .",
    "then , the regularized source at the particle location which is the source for @xmath87 , is derived as @xmath88 we show the above source as the dashed green curve in .",
    "this regular source @xmath82 behaves as `` @xmath89 for @xmath90 '' , i.e. , is @xmath81 around the particle location , and behaves as @xmath91 for large @xmath29 ( see . ) .",
    "however , it diverges as @xmath92 at the horizon ( @xmath93 ) ( see . ) .",
    "therefore , we need one more regularization at the horizon .",

    "@xmath97 here , any bad behavior at infinity does not arise from the above regularization function because we have introduced the factor @xmath98 in .",

    "this completes the results for the effective source term of the @xmath51 mode to be used in numerical calculations .        from",
    ", the singular field for the @xmath52 mode is derived as @xmath101^{1/2 } } \\nonumber \\\\ \\qquad \\times   \\theta \\left(\\frac{4\\,(2\\rho_0-m)\\rho_0 ^ 2}{(2\\rho_0+m)^3}(t - u^t\\tau)-|{\\bf x } - { \\bf x_z}|\\right )   \\nonumber \\\\ \\hspace{-5 mm } =   \\frac{q}{2\\pi } \\int_{-\\infty}^{t_{ret } } dt_0 \\ , \\frac{8\\,(2\\rho_0-m)^{1/2 } \\rho_0^{5/2}}{u^t(2\\rho_0+m)^{7/2 } }   \\nonumber \\\\   \\qquad \\times   \\frac{\\exp[{-im ( u^\\phi / u^t ) t_0 } ] } { \\left[{\\frac{16\\,(2\\rho_0-m)^2\\rho_0 ^ 4}{(2\\rho_0+m)^6}(t - t_0)^2-|{\\bf x }   - { \\bf x_z}|^2}\\right]^{1/2 } } \\ , , \\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where the new variable for integration @xmath102 , and the retarded time @xmath103 are defined by @xmath104 by introducing the following variable , @xmath105 the above integration can be done as @xmath106^{1/2 } }   \\exp({-im \\omega t } ) \\nonumber \\\\",
    "\\times   \\frac{\\exp\\{im \\omega ( 2\\rho_0+m)^3 |{\\bf x } - { \\bf x_z}|{\\cal t}/ [ 4\\,(2\\rho_0-m)\\rho_0 ^ 2 ] \\ } } { \\left({{\\cal t}^2 - 1}\\right)^{1/2 } }   \\nonumber \\\\ \\hspace{-5 mm } = \\frac{i}{4}\\,q\\,\\frac{2\\,\\sqrt{\\rho_0}\\,\\exp({-im \\omega t } ) } { u^t \\left[{(2\\rho_0+m ) ( 2\\rho_0-m)}\\right]^{1/2 } }   h_0^{(1 ) }   \\left ( \\frac{(2\\rho_0+m)^3}{4\\,(2\\rho_0-m)\\rho_0 ^ 2 } m \\omega |{\\bf x } - { \\bf x_z}| \\right ) \\,,\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where the angular frequency is given by @xmath107 and @xmath108 is the hankel function of the first kind . the local behavior of the above solution near the particle location is @xmath109^{1/2 } }   \\ln   \\left ( \\frac{(2\\rho_0+m)^3}{4\\,(2\\rho_0-m)\\rho_0 ^ 2 } m \\omega |{\\bf x } - { \\bf x_z}| \\right ) \\,.\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]      when we write the singular field as @xmath110 @xmath111 is finite at the particle location .",
    "then , the effective source in becomes @xmath112^{1/2 } }   \\ln   \\left ( \\frac{(2\\rho_0+m)^3}{4\\,(2\\rho_0-m)\\rho_0 ^ 2 } m \\omega |{\\bf x } - { \\bf x_z}| \\right ) \\nonumber \\\\ \\times   \\biggl ( -\\frac{1}{\\rho^2 \\sin^2 \\theta } \\left(m^2 - \\frac{1}{4}\\frac{(4\\rho^2+m^2)^2 - 16\\rho m \\cos^2 \\theta } { ( 2\\rho+m)^2(2\\rho - m)^2 } \\right )   \\nonumber \\\\",
    "\\qquad   -(m \\omega)^2\\left ( \\frac{(2\\rho_0+m)^6}{(2\\rho_0-m)^2\\rho_0 ^ 4 } -\\frac{(2\\rho+m)^6}{(2\\rho - m)^2\\rho^4 } \\right ) \\biggr ) - { \\cal l}_m^{rem } { \\hat \\chi}_m^s(t , r,\\theta ) \\ , , \\label{eq : cir_smeff}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]",
    "note that the third line of the above right hand side is at least @xmath81 at the location of the particle .",
    "therefore , @xmath36 shown for the @xmath113 mode by the solid red curve in , has a logarithmic divergence at the particle location .",
    "this behavior does not change for each @xmath14 mode .    to remove the logarithmic divergence in the source , we introduce @xmath114",
    "\\label{eq : rems}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] using this regularization function , we obtain a source @xmath115 for the function @xmath116 @xmath117 the local behavior of @xmath115 , which is shown by the dashed green curve in , is of the form `` @xmath89 for @xmath90 '' , i.e. , @xmath81 at the particle location .",
    "we now focus on the behavior of the source term at the two boundaries , i.e. , at the horizon of the large hole and spatial infinity .",
    "( see and [ fig : far1 ] . ) to regularize the source at the boundaries , we note that the source contribution from @xmath118 is well behaved .",
    "this means that the ill behaviors of the source arise from @xmath33 .",
    "therefore , it is convenient to use the asymptotic behavior of @xmath33 ( and some correction factor ) for regularization .    for the regularization near the horizon",
    ", we use the regularization function @xmath119 given in .",
    "then , the source for the function @xmath120 becomes @xmath121 this @xmath122 is shown by the dotted yellow curve in and vanishes as @xmath100 at the horizon . but",
    "this source behaves as @xmath123 for large @xmath29 .",
    "( see . ) to regularize it , we use the regularization function , @xmath124   \\ , .",
    "\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] the final source for the regularized function @xmath125 becomes @xmath126 this @xmath127 is shown by the dash - dotted black curve in , and behaves like @xmath128 ( an oscillation factor with respect to @xmath29 ) for large @xmath29 . using this effective source",
    ", we can calculate @xmath53 by numerical calculations .",
    "in this paper , we have formulated how to derive a global effective source , in replacement of a two - dimensional dirac s delta , for the ( 2 + 1)-dimensional klein - gordon differential equation on a black hole background by using a transformation of the scalar field in and a coordinate transformation with respect to time in . here ,",
    "since we focus on the retarded field which is global , we do not use any local analysis and of the field , but have treated only the fields , i.e. , @xmath129 , @xmath118 , @xmath99 and @xmath130 defined globally .",
    "the above treatment of the regularization functions is the feature of this paper . on the other hand , barack and golbourn @xcite",
    "have introduced a thin worldtube surrounding the worldline of a point particle , i.e. , the local analysis to derive the retarded field . in this approach",
    "it is important to obtain results that are insensitive to the choice of the size of the world tube . on the other hand , our approach ,",
    "determining a global effective source , is straightforward to use , once the regularization is done .    as the application , in the case of circular orbit , we obtained the regularized effective source @xmath127 for the field",
    "this source is @xmath81 at the location of the particle , and @xmath100 near the horizon .",
    "the behavior at infinity is @xmath54 for the @xmath51 mode and @xmath131 ( an oscillation factor with respect to @xmath29 ) for the @xmath52 modes , which allows straightforward numerical integration .    in the case of general orbits",
    ", there is some additional difficulty . if it is possible to use the slow motion approximation and the eccentricity expansion for the bounded orbit cases , we can obtain @xmath129 analytically .",
    "although we need to derive the singular field @xmath129 by numerical calculations in general , these include only the numerical integration for and .",
    "the regularization functions @xmath119 and @xmath130 for the field @xmath34 are extracted from the asymptotic behavior directly .",
    "this is the same method used in the circular case .",
    "about the regularization functions @xmath118 , using with the source which is evaluated from the asymptotic behavior of @xmath36 , we can derive @xmath118 by a numerical integration because we need only the most singular part around the particle s location .",
    "hence , there is no trouble to obtain the effective source for @xmath53 .",
    "when we consider the extension of this formulation to the kerr background case , we can also extract a similar differential operator to that of . in practice",
    ", we have the ( 2 + 1)-dimensional dalambertian of the flat spacetime in this case .",
    "the mode decomposition only in the azimuthal direction has already been used , therefore , the same treatment discussed in this paper is applicable .    finally , in the case of gravitational perturbations , we have ten field equations for the linear perturbation in the lorenz gauge .",
    "( see @xcite . )",
    "we can also extract the ( 2 + 1)-dimensional dalambertian of the flat spacetime from them .",
    "the same treatment also holds to those equations .",
    "the method can also be used to deal with the teukolsky differential equation @xcite with the corresponding corrections for the presence of not only dirac s delta but first and second derivatives of it as source terms .",
    "we would like to thank n.  sago and h.  tagoshi for useful discussions .",
    "this is supported by jsps for research abroad ( hn ) , by the nsf through grants phy-0722315 , phy-0701566 , phy-0714388 , and phy-0722703 , and from grant nasa 07-atfp07 - 0158 .",
    "to obtain @xmath33 from we use the green s function method . here",
    "we consider the green s function in the cartesian coordinates , i.e. , @xmath132 and @xmath133 @xmath134 where @xmath135 denotes the 2-dimensional @xmath0-function .",
    "a solution of the above equation is usually calculated by using the fourier transformation , @xmath136 in the frequency domain , the green s function satisfies the equation , @xmath137 the green s function must become a homogeneous solution of the above equation for @xmath138 . and , near the singularity , @xmath139",
    ", the green s function must behave as @xmath140 .",
    "furthermore , we need to set a boundary condition . the out - going boundary condition is used here . from the above three conditions ,",
    "the green s function in the frequency domain is obtained as @xmath141 where @xmath108 is the hankel functions of the first kind .",
    "we go back to the time domain by using .",
    "@xmath142 \\,.\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] note that @xmath143 . here",
    ", we use an integral representation of the hankel functions @xmath144 and then , the green s function in the time domain is derived as @xmath145^{1/2 } } \\theta((t - t')-|{\\bf x } - { \\bf x'}| ) \\,.\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] from the above heaviside step function , this green s function has support not only on the light cone , but also inside the light cone .",
    "this is mentioned as a failure of the huygens principle @xcite .",
    "this feature of the green s function has been discussed in refs .",
    "the above green s function is also derived from the direct integration of the ( 3 + 1)-dimensional green s function with respect to the axial direction @xcite .",
    "the function @xmath119 for the regularization near the horizon is so long that we summarize it in this appendix .",
    "@xmath146^{1/2}\\,\\rho ^{4 } } \\,\\exp ( - i\\,m\\,\\omega \\,t ) \\nonumber \\\\   \\times \\biggl\\ { c_0 ( \\rho,\\,\\theta ) h_0^{(1 ) } \\left [ \\frac{(2\\rho_0+m)^3}{4\\,(2\\rho_0-m)\\rho_0 ^ 2 } m \\omega   \\sqrt{f(\\theta)}\\right ]   \\nonumber \\\\ \\qquad +   c_1 ( \\rho,\\,\\theta ) h_1^{(1 ) } \\left [ \\frac{(2\\rho_0+m)^3}{4\\,(2\\rho_0-m)\\rho_0 ^ 2 } m \\omega   \\sqrt{f(\\theta)}\\right ]   \\nonumber \\\\ \\qquad   + c_2 ( \\rho,\\,\\theta ) h_2^{(1 ) } \\left [ \\frac{(2\\rho_0+m)^3}{4\\,(2\\rho_0-m)\\rho_0 ^ 2 } m \\omega   \\sqrt{f(\\theta ) } \\right ]   \\biggr\\ } \\ , , \\label{eq : chimh}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where @xmath147 \\left(\\rho   - { \\displaystyle \\frac { m}{2 } } \\right)^{2 } \\left/ { \\vrule   height0.44em width0em depth0.44em } \\right . \\ !   \\",

    "\\theta \\nonumber \\\\    + 7348\\,\\rho_0^{3}\\,m^{6}\\ , \\sin \\theta\\,\\cos^2 \\theta    - 68992\\,\\rho_0^{5}\\,m^{4}\\,\\sin \\theta   + 12496\\,m^{5}\\,\\rho_0^{4}\\,\\cos^4 \\theta \\nonumber \\\\     - 292\\,\\rho_0\\,m^{8}\\,\\sin \\theta    - 2095\\,m^{7}\\,\\rho_0^{2}\\,\\cos^2 \\theta   + 34048\\,m^{5}\\,\\rho_0^{4 } \\biggr ] m\\,\\omega \\,(2\\,\\rho_0 + m)^{3 } \\nonumber \\\\",

    "\\biggl [ ( - 2\\,\\rho_0 + m)\\,m\\,\\rho_0^{2}\\,(m^{2 } + 4 \\,\\rho_0^{2 } - 4\\,\\rho_0\\,\\sin \\theta\\,m)^{9/2 }   \\nonumber \\\\    \\times ( 9 + 64\\,m^{2}\\,m^{2}\\,\\omega ^{2 } )   \\biggr ]    \\ , , \\nonumber \\\\",
    "\\fl   c_2 ( \\rho,\\,\\theta )   = { \\displaystyle \\frac { 1}{64 } }   ( m^{2 } - 4\\,\\rho_0\\,\\sin \\theta\\,m + 4\\,\\rho_0^{2 }   - 4\\,\\cos^2 \\theta\\,\\rho_0^{2})\\,\\omega ^{2 } \\,m^{2}(2\\,\\rho_0 + m)^{6 } ( 64\\,m^{2}\\,m^{2}\\,\\omega ^{2 } \\nonumber \\\\",

    "d.  v.  galtsov , phys .",

    "v.  cardoso , o.  j.  c.  dias and j.  p.  s.  lemos , phys .",
    "d * 67 * , 064026 ( 2003 ) [ arxiv : hep - th/0212168 ] ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> unlike in the schwarzschild black hole background , gravitational perturbations in a kerr black hole background can not be decomposed into simple tensor harmonics in the time domain . here , we make mode decompositions only in the azimuthal direction . as a first step , </S>",
    "<S> we discuss the resulting ( 2 + 1)-dimensional klein - gordon differential equation for scalar perturbations with a two dimensional dirac s @xmath0-function as a source representing a point particle orbiting a much larger black hole . to make this equation amenable for numerical integrations we explicitly remove analytically the singular behavior of the source and compute a global , well behaved , effective source for the corresponding waveform . </S>"
  ]
}
